text: @emiliehayter I can, and will argue with it, because that isn't what the advert said to me at all. What you must remember is that this is a matter of perception, and you clearly perceived this differently. However I like thousands of others did not like the message we received and if your offended by an opinion then I can't help you unfortunately,

@dangerousdibs It's not an issue that applies to both men and women in the same way as you say. 
What the ad criticises: the toxic masculinity that leads to 1/5 women being sexually assaulted, 2 a week killed by an ex-partner and 75% of suicides in the UK being male.
What it does not criticise: being male 
I watched the Gillette ad. It made me proud knowing I have male friends that would stand up for me like the guys who step in to help the harassed women. It made me feel more confident about speaking out when I'm in an uncomfortable situation and asking for help rather than keeping my eyes down and mouth shut pretending it's not happening. It made me feel for boys who get horrifically bullied at school yet the stigma behind telling someone is too great. Finally it made me have much more respect for those who agree with the moral stance of the advert regardless of the product.
Standing up for those you see who are being oppressed. Who can argue with that?
@emiliehayter I'm not saying that at all, you are. What I'm saying is something that applies to both men and women shouldn't be a male centred advertisement...it's meant to be about equality right? 😂

@dangerousdibs 
So you're saying that because you've never had a sexist attitude then you are exempt from ever hearing about the problem?
You shouldn't feel personally attacked by an ad that promotes anti-bullying and anti-harassment movements and therefore throw away their products. 
The term “toxic masculinity” is not implying that all masculinity is toxic, it’s saying that some actions that are blamed on being masculine is simply toxic behaviour that needs to be fixed. If you ignore the problem then you are part of the problem.
@littlemac1991 black Sabbath can't help some people bud 😂😂😂

I get groped by old.ladies in town all the time....but maybe that's just because my ass is fantastic. Id probably ignore anything I say though because I give 0 fucks either way, both sides are too soft and sensitive. Everyone has to have something to moan about. Just be happy for fucks sake, eat what you want train what you want do what you want, listen to some black Sabbath, have a great time
@emiliehayter who said that any of that is acceptable. My masculinity has never done any of that so why should I be told it's a problem?

Urghhh this debate isn't women=good, men=bad. Men need to hold other men accountable for their actions. My 'femininity' has never groped a stranger's crotch, forced sex without consent and changed someone's route to work because of continued harassment, but it's okay to say that this is acceptable under the term masculinity?
If your masculinity hurts people in the way the advert shows, then no wonder you're feeling defensive. 
Support your sisters, girlfriends, future daughters in standing up against sexual harassment. Equality benefits everyone.
I'm sorry if I've offended your femininity which has never hurt anyone.... 🤣🤣🤣🤣🤣🤣
If your masculinity can't watch an advert that encourages positive behaviours and zero tolerance on sexual harassment without demanding a boycott, maybe it's time to reevaluate...
What is this lunacy all about?
